questions.question: Which of the following is not an anticholinergic drug?
What is the scientific name of this plant whose roots & leaves were historically used inthe treatment of asthma?
questions.explanation: The above plant is Datura stramonium, also called Jamestown or Jimsonweed.The active ingredient in Datura stramonium includes anticholinergic alkaloids such as atropine,scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. These were helpful in relieving the symptoms associated withasthma via inhibition of M3 receptors on bronchi, leading to a decrease in bronchospasm andtracheobronchial secretions.

questions.question: 112On administration of atropine, which of the following effects is unlikely?
questions.explanation: 120Atropine does not cause increased bowel sounds. It decreases the amplitude and frequency ofperistalsis, resulting in decreased bowel sounds.Peristalsis suppression due to atropine is incomplete because of the additional control ofperistalsis by local reflexes in the enteric nervous system and involvement of otherneurotransmitters like 5-HT, encephalin, dopamine in peristalsis.Actions of atropine:•Mydriasis by blocking the contraction of sphincter pupillae muscle-• Decreased secretions from salivary glands and lacrimal glands - by blocking M1 & M3receptors•Tachycardia - due to its vagolytic activity at M2 receptor• Decreased sweating - by inhibiting sympathetic cholinergic supply to sweat glands which makesthe skin hot and dry (atropine fever).

questions.question: While treating a patient with acute myocardial infarction, an abnormal rhythm was noted onthe ECG. The senior resident decides to administer atropine to control this. What was thelikely rhythm observed in the patient?
questions.explanation: Atropine is indicated in acute myocardial infarction when it is accompanied by sinus bradycardiadue to excessive vagal tone. It is seen commonly in inferior or posterior wall myocardialinfarction.The dosage of atropine has to be carefully adjusted when used in a patient with myocardialinfarction. If the dose is too low it will aggravate the bradycardia by action on presynapticM1 receptors. If the dose is too high it will cause significant tachycardia and aggravate thecondition by competitive inhibition of postsynaptic M2 receptors.

questions.question: You administer atropine at a dose of 0.5 mg IV to a patient with symptomatic bradycardia.What would be the effect on heart rate?
questions.explanation: Atropine at average clinical doses of 0.4-0.6 mg administered parenterally results in transientbradycardia followed by tachycardia.Parasympathetic postganglionic nerve terminals in the SA node contain presynaptic M1 receptors.These receptors normally inhibit the release of ACh. Therefore stimulation of these receptorsdecreases the release of ACh causing tachycardia. Inhibition of these receptors increases AChcausing bradycardia.Atropine initially blocks these presynaptic M1 receptors. This increases the amount of AChreleased at the SA node and causes bradycardia. Then, the progressive increase in the atropineconcentration blocks the postsynaptic M2 receptors on the SA node (decreasing the ACh release)decreasing the parasympathetic tone, thereby causing tachycardia.

questions.question: A delirious child was rushed to the ER with a history of ingestion of an unknown plant. Onexamination, his pulse rate was 150 beats per minute, and his skin was warm and dry. Pupilswere dilated and bowel sounds were sluggish. Which of the following toxidromes is likely tobe responsible for the symptoms in this child?
questions.explanation: 121Mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth, atropine fever (warm, hot skin) and delirium are classicalsymptoms of anticholinergic overdose following the ingestion of plants that contain belladonnaalkaloids.Physostigmine is the drug of choice for the treatment of atropine and belladonna poisoning.Atropa BelladonnaBelladonna -Beautiful womanAtropine OverdoseHot as a hare(TTemperature)Mad as a hatter(Confusion, Delirium)Blind as a bat(Mydriasis)Red as a beet(Flushed face)Dry as a bone(+Secretions, thirsty)©MARROWOption B: Sympathomimetics can cause mydriasis and tachycardia. Hyperthermia can be seensecondary to increased agitation and aggressive movements. However, delirium is rare and bowelsounds would be normal or increased in sympathomimetic toxidromes.Option C: Opioid overdose results in decreased bowel sounds but other symptoms are not seen.Option D: In sedative-hypnotic toxidrome, CNS depression and reduced bowel sounds are seen.But it does not cause tachycardia or change in pupil diameter.

questions.question: Which of the following would you use in the treatment of atropine toxicity?
questions.explanation: Atropine toxicity is treated with physostigmine, a reversible anticholinesterase agent.Physostigmine acts by decreasing the breakdown of acetylcholine, and it also overcomes thecompetitive blockade of atropine in all muscarinic receptors.122Atropa BelladonnaBelladonnaBeautiful womanAtropine OverdoseRHot as a hare(↑ Temperature)Mad as a hatter(Confusion, Delirium)Blind as a bat(Mydriasis)Red as a beet(Flushed face)Dry as a bone(+Secretions, thirsty)OMARROW

questions.question: You are monitoring a patient being treated with atropine for alleged consumption of anorganophosphate compound. Suddenly he develops marked excitement and claims to see hislate wife sitting next to him. All of the following can be used in the management of thispatient except?
questions.explanation: The clinical features of marked excitement and hallucinations are seen in atropine toxicity.Chlorpromazine should be avoided in patients with atropine toxicity.Chlorpromazine is a low potency typical antipsychotic having high anticholinergicactivity. Administering phenothiazines like chlorpromazine will worsen atropine toxicity.Atropa BelladonnaBelladonna -Beautiful womanAtropine OverdoseHot as a hare(†Temperature)RMad as a hatter(Confusion, Delirium)Blind as a bat(Mydriasis)Red as a beet(Flushed face)Dry as a bone(+Secretions, thirsty)MARROWOption A: Physostigmine is indicated as first-line therapy for atropine intoxicationOption B and D: Benzodiazepines can be used when marked excitement is present to calm downthe patient123

questions.question: Atropine is indicated in all of the following poisonings except
questions.explanation: Endrin is an organochloride pesticide that causes neurotoxicity. There is no antidote availableand only symptomatic treatment is done.Parathion and TIK20 are organophosphates and baygon is a combination of organophosphate andcarbamate. For all of these, atropine is the drug of choice.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the mechanism of mydriasis due to the instillation of amuscarinic antagonist?

options.A: Contraction of the sphincter pupillae of the iris114
options.B: Paralysis of the dilator pupillae muscles of the iris
options.C: Contraction of the dilator pupillae muscles of the iris
options.D: Paralysis of the sphincter pupillae of the iris

questions.explanation: Mydriatic action of a muscarinic antagonist is due to the paralysis of the sphincterpupillae (circular) muscle of the iris.In the iris, miosis occurs due to the constriction of the pupillary sphincter muscles and mydriasisis due to the contraction of the dilator pupillae (radial) muscles. They counter-balance each other.When muscarinic antagonists are instilled, the pupillary sphincter muscle is paralyzed, causingmydriasis due to the unopposed contraction of the dilator pupillae muscle.Adrenergic alpha agonists also cause mydriasis, but by mediating the contraction of the dilatorpupillae muscle of iris.Parasympatholytic drugs are classified as:ClassDrugsMuscarinic antagonistsNicotinic antagonistsNmantagonistsNon-depolarizingAtropineScopolamineHomatropineTropicamideIpratropium, TiotropiumDarifenacin, Solifenacin Pirenzipine, TelenzipineGlycopyrrolate UmeclidiniumNnantagonistsTrimethaphanHexamethoniumMecamylamineDepolarizingSuxamethonium DecamethoniumPancuroniumVecuroniumRocuroniumd-tubocurarineMivacuriumAtracurium

questions.question: To achieve which of the following states will you use phenylephrine instead of atropine?
questions.explanation: Atropine is substituted by phenylephrine in situations where mydriasis is required withoutcycloplegia, like in fundoscopy.Phenylephrine, an alpha 1 agonist, acts on the radial muscle (dilator pupillae) of the iris andcauses isolated mydriasis. It has no cycloplegic action because sympathetic receptors are presentonly on the iris and not on the ciliary body.124Atropine has both mydriatic and cycloplegic action, which is required for refraction testing.In elderly people who have a low ciliary tone, phenylephrine is preferred as a mydriatic. This isbecause other anticholinergics can precipitate or aggravate glaucoma by relaxation of the ciliarybody and altering the forces acting on trabecular meshwork for aqueous outflow.Atropine, cyclopentolate, and tropicamide are antimuscarinics that are available for ophthalmicuse and cause cycloplegia to a variable extent. This cycloplegia/paralysis of accommodation occursdue to their parasympatholytic action, which decreases the tone of the ciliary body.

questions.question: Which of the following is a short-acting mydriatic that you can use for performing afundoscopy?
questions.explanation: Tropicamide is a short-acting mydriatic used in fundoscopy.It has a rapid onset (20-40 minutes) and a brief duration of action (3-6 hours). The cycloplegiaproduced by tropicamide is unreliable and insignificant. It is indicated for fundoscopy andrefraction testing in adults who have a relatively low ciliary tone when compared to children.Atropine, which produces complete cycloplegia, is preferred in children as they have a higherciliary tone. Atropine is usually preferred over other mydriatics for accurate refractory errortesting because of reliable cycloplegia. However, it can also precipitate an acute attack ofglaucoma and should not be used in patients with glaucoma.

questions.question: A 70-year-old diabetic patient presents to the OPD for diabetic retinopathy screening. Whywould you prefer phenylephrine over other anticholinergic drugs as a mydriatic agent beforeperforming fundoscopy?

options.A: High ciliary tone in elderly patients
options.C: Phenylephrine can decrease ciliary tone in elderly patients

questions.explanation: Phenylephrine is preferred in elderly people as other anticholinergics can precipitate or aggravateglaucoma.Elderly people have low ciliary tone, and phenylephrine does not alter the tone of the ciliarybody. Other anticholinergics cause relaxation of the ciliary body and alter the forces acting ontrabecular meshwork for aqueous outflow.

questions.question: 115A young man with a history of motion sickness presents to your OPD with upcoming plans fora road trip. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?

options.B: Ondansetran one night before and also before trip

questions.explanation: Scopolamine (Hyoscine) transdermal patch is the most appropriate treatment for motion sicknessbefore a trip.It should be applied behind the ear about 5-6 hours before the journey, and gives protection foraround 72 hours against motion sickness, after which the patch can be replaced if necessary.Scopolamine is also used for narcoanalysis as it causes sedation and amnesia.Dimenhydrinate is a first-generation antihistamine that can also be used in motion sickness.Although dimenhydrinate may have equal efficacy it is not preferred because of its sedatingproperties.125

questions.question: Which of the following conditions can be treated with pirenzepine?
questions.explanation: Pirenzepine is used for treating gastric ulcers. It is a selective M1 anticholinergic drug. Itdecreases gastric acid secretions at doses that have little effect on salivation or heart rate.

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman diagnosed with diarrhoea-predominant irritable bowel syndromepresented to the casualty with severe abdominal pain. She was prescribed a drug that exerts adirect spasmolytic effect on the smooth muscles of the gastrointestinal tract. Which drugcould it be?
questions.explanation: Dicyclomine is a weak muscarinic receptor antagonist with non-specific direct spasmolytic effectson the smooth muscle of the gastrointestinal tract.Other options:Option B: Scopolamine exerts spasmolytic activity indirectly through its antimuscarinic action. Itis not preferred due to its adverse effects like drowsiness, dryness, and blurred vision.Option C and D: Galantamine and rivastigmine are central cholinesterase inhibitors and do notpossess spasmolytic activity.

questions.question: Which of the following agents shows M3 receptor selectivity?
questions.explanation: M3 receptor selectivity is shown by solifenacin and darifenacin.Oxybutynin and trospium do not show any selectivity. Tolterodine has a more specific action onthe urinary bladder but subtype selectivity is absent.

questions.question: Among the following antimuscarinic drugs used in the treatment of overactive bladder, whichone shows direct spasmolytic activity on smooth muscles?
questions.explanation: Oxybutynin is an antimuscarinic drug indicated in the overactive bladder that also exerts a directspasmolytic action on the smooth muscles of the bladder.Direct spasmolytic activity is the direct smooth muscle relaxation effect independent of relaxationcaused by antimuscarinic action.The most important adverse effects caused by the use of muscarinic antagonists for an overactivebladder are xerostomia (most common reason for discontinuation), blurred vision, and GI sideeffects like constipation and dyspepsia (due to blockade of M1, M2 & M3). Drowsiness,dizziness, and confusion can also occur.Tolterodine, darifenacin, and solifenacin are antimuscarinic agents but they do not have theadditional direct antispasmodic effect.

questions.question: Which of the following is not true regarding the effects of muscarinic antagonists on theurinary bladder?

options.C: Lowers the frequency of bladder contractions

questions.explanation: Muscarinic antagonists increase bladder capacity by blocking M3 receptors on the detrusor. Thisresults in the relaxation of the bladder.126Effects of muscarinic antagonists on the bladder:• Lowers intravesicular pressure•Increases bladder capacity• Lowers the frequency of bladder contractions•Alters bladder sensation during filling

questions.question: After suffering from a stroke, a middle-aged patient was diagnosed with overactive bladderdue to detrusor instability. Which of the following drugs is not useful in this condition?
questions.explanation: Duloxetine is not useful in detrusor instability. It is a selective serotonin and norepinephrinereuptake inhibitor that is efficacious in stress urinary incontinence. It is also indicatedin depression, fibromyalgia, and neuropathic pain.Muscarinic antagonists are useful in this case. They increase bladder capacity by blocking M3receptors on detrusor. This results in the relaxation of the bladder.The effects of muscarinic antagonists on the bladder are:• Lowering of intravesicular pressure•• Increases bladder capacity• Lower the frequency of bladder contractions• Alter bladder sensation during filling

questions.question: In a patient with overactive bladder, what is the most common reason for him to discontinuetreatment with muscarinic antagonists?
questions.explanation: Xerostomia is the most common reason for the discontinuation of muscarinic antagonists inoveractive bladder.The most important adverse effects caused by the use of muscarinic antagonists for an overactivebladder are xerostomia, blurred vision, and GI side effects like constipation and dyspepsia (due toblockade of M1, M2 & M3). Drowsiness, dizziness, and confusion can also occur.

questions.question: Which of the following has selective action on M1 and M3 receptors?
questions.explanation: Tiotropium has a selective action on M1 and M3 receptors.Tiotropium binds to all M1, M2 and M3 receptors. However, it dissociates slower from M1 and M3receptors as compared to M2. This shows it has a higher affinity towards M1 and M3 receptors.Ipratropium and atropine methonitrate do not have any subtype selectivity on muscarinicreceptors.Inhibition of mucociliary clearance by atropine results in the accumulation of lower airwaysecretions and the formation of mucus plugs. However, tiotropium and ipratropium haveminimum interference with mucociliary clearance when compared to atropine, and the incidence127of mucus plugs is also less.

questions.question: In which of the following patients is the use of trospium contraindicated?
questions.explanation: The use of trospium is contraindicated in urinary retention. It is an antimuscarinic agent and canworsen urinary retention.Muscarinic antagonists are contraindicated in urinary tract obstruction and in benign prostatichyperplasia (or used with extreme caution).Bronchial asthma, hypertension, and peptic ulcer disease are not the contraindications for the useof trospium.

questions.question: Which of the following does not produce central anticholinergic syndrome?
questions.explanation: Glycopyrrolate usually does not produce central anticholinergic syndrome. It is a quaternaryamine compound and lipid insoluble. Therefore, glycopyrrolate does not cross the blood-brainbarrier.Non-depolarising skeletal muscle relaxants are used in anesthesia. Neostigmine along withglycopyrrolate are used for reversal of this neuromuscular block. Glycopyrrolate blocks theperipheral muscarinic side effects due to the increased acetylcholine levels after theadministration of neostigmine, without causing unwanted central anticholinergic effects.Peripheral and central anticholinergic syndromes are reactions due to either overdose or anyunusual reaction to the usage of drugs like atropine and other muscarinic agents, phenothiazines,antihistamines, and tricyclic antidepressantsOption B: Atropine is a tertiary compound that can cross the blood-brain barrier and cause centralanticholinergic syndrome.Option C and D: Some of the first-generation antihistamines and tricyclic antidepressants havesignificant anticholinergic activity and can cause central anticholinergic syndrome.

questions.question: Which of the following is most commonly used for narcoanalysis?
questions.explanation: The most commonly used drug in narcoanalysis is pentothal sodium (thiopentone).Other drugs used in narcoanalysis are sodium amytal and secobarbital.Scopolamine hydrochloride was also used in narcoanalysis during World War II. It was popularlyknown as the 'lie detector'. The amnesic and depressant actions of scopolamine are due to theinhibition of the brain cholinergic system. It would put the subject off guard in case of sustainedinterrogation and sleep deprivation, eventually forcing the truth out.128

questions.question: Inhibitory effect on mucociliary clearance is minimal with which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation: Both ipratropium and tiotropium have a minimal inhibitory effect on mucociliary clearance whencompared to atropine. Inhibition of mucociliary clearance by atropine results in accumulation oflower airway secretions and formation of mucus plugs.129
